**Value**: 31 mg/m³ (10 ppm)
46 mg/m³ (15 ppm)

GRAS listed. Accepted for use as a food additive in Europe. In cheese products, propionates are limited to 0.3% w/w concentration; a limit of 0.32% w/w is applied in flour and white bread rolls, while a limit of 0.38% w/w is applied in whole wheat products. Included in the FDA Inactive Ingredients Database (oral capsules, powder, suspensions, and syrups). Included in nonparenteral medicines licensed in the UK. Included in the Canadian List of Acceptable Non-medicinal Ingredients.
Anhydrous sodium propionate; calcium propionate; potassium propionate; propionic acid; zinc propionate.
C₃H₅O₂Na
E281; propanoic acid, sodium salt, anhydrous.
C₆H₁₀O₄Ca
Calcium dipropionate; E282; propanoic acid, calcium salt; propionic acid, calcium salt.
White crystalline powder.
Soluble in water; slightly soluble in ethanol (95%) and methanol; practically insoluble in acetone and benzene.
Prepared by the reaction of propionic acid and calcium hydroxide.
Occurs as the monohydrate or trihydrate.
C₃H₅O₂K
E283; propanoic acid, potassium salt; propionic acid, potassium salt.
White crystalline powder.
Occurs as the anhydrous form and the monohydrate. Decomposes in moist air to give off propionic acid.
C₁H₆O₄Zn
Propanoic acid, zinc salt; propionic acid, zinc salt.
White platelets or needlelike crystals (for the monohydrate).
The anhydrous form is soluble 1 in 36 of ethanol (95%) at 158°C, 1 in 6 of boiling ethanol (95%), and 1 in 3 of water at 158°C.
Prepared by dissolving zinc oxide in dilute propionic acid solution.
Occurs as the anhydrous form and the monohydrate. Decomposes in moist air to give off propionic acid.
Propionates are used as antimicrobial preservatives in preference to propionic acid since they are less corrosive.
